title: Friday, 26th April 2019
bodyHTML:

Which leads us over to AstraZeneca I guess.

AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 5,898, up 9 (+0.15%), High: 6,035, Low: 5,817, Volume: 932.09k

chopper bear silence therapeutics up 40% this week

Unchanged on better than expected Q1s

PBateman Could we take a look at Hastings if there's any time please?
FjordFiesta @Patience after some reflection I've decided the correct response was 'CBD, CBA'

3% beat on product sales, mostly on oncolocy (4% beat) and heart stuff (6% beat)

Nately Police are too busy catching me doing 35 in a 30. Happy Friday.

Guidance unchanged though, and questions regarding the externalisation strategy still front and centre.

Patience @Fjord - CBA?

Plus, of course, the stealth rights issue that was disguised by the Daicchi thing.

Excel Developer oops, http://www.affinity-consulting.com/Graphs/FTSE-30-since-1935-Log-scale.pdf
Kiwi-juice good morning
FjordFiesta @Patience Can't Be Ar$...

BE11:15am

Guidance unchanged, nothing on pipeline. All kind of dull. Probably not 100% Minimum Projected Return.

BE11:15am

Have Caz.

Kiwi-juice Good call yesterday from the broker upgrading Hastings. Can we get grey on that? Is that a blip we can buy? Also would love grey on Bayer. Rare to have a megacap on 10% FCF Yield
BE11:15am

With shares having been weak since the Daiichi deal / equity raise, in part due to concerns around the company’s ability to deliver on margin expansion, we believe today’s strong results should provide some reassurance, and hence we expect shares to outperform by a couple of % today.
Astra trades on c.19x 2020E Core EPS, for a 15% 2020E-23E EPS CAGR; we think the stock looks good value vs. large cap peers on c.15x 2020E PE for a 6% CAGR over the same time period. We remain Overweight in light of the sector leading growth outlook, improving earnings quality, upside around Tagrisso expectations and optionality around the broad late stage pipeline.
As expected, cash generation was weak this quarter. Net cash outflow from operating activities was $387m, vs. $140m outflow in the prior year, in part due to one-off payments related to prior business development activities. Cash generation was also negatively impacted yoy by higher tax payments and higher interest expense. We expect Cash generation to remain depressed for the remainder of 2019, as well flagged by the company, before improving from 2020 onward, largely as a result of accelerating product sales growth, and operating margin expansion.

11:15 am
undefined

(@Nately: have you considered not doing 35 in a 30?)

And unless that changes, profit margins get squeezed.

11:18 am

Loss ratio expected to move towards the higher end of the 75-79% target range ......

PBateman hstg seems overdone
Excel Developer @Patience good for you. @waynej was asking about the first post war crash for UK equities yesterday.
BE11:19am

... The prior guidance, which was for middle of the range, assumds a turn in the cycle in mid year.

RuminationsOn @BE - is there an explainer as to what happens next in the Chevron/Oxy/Anadarko game - given that no one else has a takeoever panel (no comment) does raw nature just win out? Or doe we just wait for CVX to say nothing in 1Q results at US open?
PBateman 1/2ish profit comes from fees and installment income that underwriting has no effect on
BE11:20am

Now, Hastings is tricky because it's growing.

Patience @BE - read a heavy plug for Hastings earlier this week when they were at 220. Fortunately I don't invest in companies under £3bn market cap - at least not any more.
11:20 am
BE11:20am

But the loss ratio -- total losses divided by the total premiums, IIRC -- is a lot more important than the policy count.

BE11:21am

A 1% move in the combined ratio (which is the loss ratio divided by the expense ratio, I think ... insurers are super fun!) moves Hastings EPS by 6% or so.

BE11:21am

Whereas a 1% improvement in the customer count only adds 1% to EPS.

BornCynic Can I add another request for Stagecoach please BE.
PBateman Combined is expense plus loss ratio
Kiwi-juice Is combined ratio not expense ratio+loss ratio?
11:21 am
BE11:22am

Cazenove were the shop that upgraded Hastings earlier in the week.

Soundbuy @ Patience - one in the eye for whoever tipped Hastings.............
BE11:22am

(@PBateman: sorry, did I say divided? Whatever.)

BE11:22am

They say this.

Kiwi-juice Hastings has 15% expense ratio so they will still be profitable and able to grow share. I hear their reserving is aggressive, that is what is hitting them maybe today (fears that profits will vanish)?
Maudise RE: off the chart, surely you just make a bigger chart?
Patience @Soundbuy - but avoided one in the eye myself :-)
11:23 am
BE11:23am

Hastings has this morning reported its Q1 trading statement covering the period to 31 March 2019. There is a modest return to growth in this period, with Live Customer Policies +1.5% QoQ to 2.75m, fractionally above the +1% implied by our estimate. Gross Written Premium is +4% YoY (we have +5% for the FY), however net revenue is -1% (we have +5% for the FY) due to lower earn through of premium and lower reinsurance income.

BE11:24am

The growth appears to be a result of higher retention rates, with Hastings continuing to cite a competitive market that continues to see “high” levels of claims inflation. For this reason it currently expects its FY19 loss ratio to be towards the higher end of the 75-79% target range {previously ~mid-point, which is assumed in our estimates}. In our view these comments again highlight the challenging trading conditions for the entire UK
motor sector, which in our view is still in a period of margin compression.

Peanut Does it work for a hangover ?
Maudise @BE Anything on RBS Q1 results today / Bank reporting would be interesting to those of that disposition
BE11:24am

Live customer policies +3% YoY. LCPs rose to 2.75m in the period, +1.5% from the figure at year-end and fractionally ahead of the run rate implied in our estimates. Hastings states that it tested a new renewal model in the period, which resulted in renewal rates rising by 4ppts.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

 Gross premiums +4% YoY. Gross premiums rose +4% YoY, close to the +5% that we assume for the FY. Net revenue is -1% YoY, which the company ascribes to lower earned premium rates and lower reinsurance income. This is below the +5% we currently assume for the FY.

BE11:25am

 Loss ratio expected to increase. Hastings describes “high” levels of claims inflation across the industry, and competitive market conditions. It now sees its FY19 loss ratio towards the higher end of the 75-79% range {previously this was seen at the mid-point and we assume 77.1%}. In our view this highlights the competitive pressures across the motor industry and we believe all peers {Admiral, Direct Line, Saga} are likely to be seeing similar trends.

BE11:25am

 Expenses. Hastings states that it has started to see benefits from its focus on operational efficiencies and digitalization, but that expenses in 2019 are likely to increase in 2019, due in part to changes to UK law on VAT recoveries and increases in the FSCS and Motor Insurers’ Bureau levies. We already include a higher level of costs in our model – it is possible that these changes result in a slightly higher than expected level however.
 Outlook. Hastings states that it will continue to monitor the higher level of claims inflation, and that its loss ratio will depend on the market environment for the rest of the year. The new guidance is based on current trends persisting, and Hastings states that it believe it can deliver profitable growth from 2020 and beyond. In our view the 2019 year is likely to see a step back in profitability – we already assume a -13% decline YoY and this statement suggests some modest risk to our estimates.

GBKrona @BE - second any analyst comment on RBS please
11:25 am
BE11:25am

And Peel Hunt, also positive.

BE11:26am

As expected, Hastings is letting Insurance margins slip within the target
range in 2019 (75-79% loss ratio) helping the Retail broker retain its competitive edge but at the expense of a margin squeeze. Hastings is feeling the inevitable effects of a plateauing cycle but is technologically ahead of the competition which gives the company a significant advantage in the current market environment. We believe the company will continue to balance volume growth against achieving its targeted margins. Hastings trades at an attractive 11x P/E 2020e supported by a c6% yield.

undefined
FjordFiesta re RBS always looks good when the CEO leaves the day before results
PBateman re hstg, 2019 weather looking v. benign so far - no beast from the east like q1 last yr
PBateman (should) help that LR come in below 79% with a tail wind
11:26 am

RBS? Guess so.

Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 239.10, down 10.9 (-4.36%), High: 243.70, Low: 232.50, Volume: 12.89m
BE11:29am

But it's a bank, so you can just pick which line you want to read based on whether you're positive or negative.

11:28 am
BE11:29am

Cost cutting and low impairments result in a £1bn profit! Which is 13% ahead of consensus!

Maudise @FJord - it's a 12 month handover, not an ejection really. Conversation this time last year was the same would he/ wouldn't he
Plato the Cook RBS CEO leaving: rat? Low hanging fruit all gone? Or a job well done?
BE11:29am

But total income of £3bn misses by 7%!

marktime Did Stephen Locket senior ind non-exec at Ferrexpo resign before or after the board announced their unanimous view that Zhevago the CEO, 50% shareholder and Ukranian MP "does not have significant influence" over their charity vehicle Blooming Land
BornCynic Went to see the Avengers film last night - the cinema did not have one empty seat that I could see - that film must be making so much money.
BE11:30am

Which is largely because of Natwest Markets, where total income was down 41% yoy.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Let me chuck some grey at this. I'm bored with typing about it.

BE11:31am

Citigroup will do.

BE11:32am

Citi's Take — Statutory PBT of £1.0bn is +13% vs consensus, helped by lower
litigation & restructuring costs. In contrast adj. PBT (excl. litigation, strategic costs & FVOD) of £1.3bn is 8% below consensus, with weaker revenues (5% below) and costs (1% heavy), part offset by lower impairments (48% better). Divisional results are complicated by restatements (Business Banking moved to Commercial). We would argue that the results are low quality. We have a Buy rating, target 295p.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

More Capital Return To Come – 16.2% CET1 ratio is stable qoq, despite IFRS16 and dividend accrual of 2p. This implies £4.2bn of excess capital vs the target c14% CET1 ratio and would seem to imply a healthy rise in the ordinary dividend (from 5.5p in FY18). Combining the 4.99% directed buyback from the UKGI (c£1.5bn), the annualized ordinary dividend accrual (8.0p, or c£0.9bn) and assuming a stable special dividend yoy (7.5p, or c£0.9bn) points to a minimum all-in yield of 11.4% for 2019, which we believe could potentially then rise to c14% over time.

Maudise @Borncynic - yes, walking through town y.day and several separate 'non-traditional demographic' groups of their target audience were discussing going to see it. Wonder how much of it is to see "Surely this has to be the end" Vs. love of a franchise
wayneJ @Excel - following on from yesterday - it looks to me that the FTSE has a proper big downward spike once every 30 years or so?
BE11:33am

Put me in a Delorian, send me back ten years and tell 2009 me that RBS has £4.2bn of excess capital.

Patience @wayneJ - a generational learning experience?
wayneJ The Silence shareholder list has some names who are a blast from the past...
BE11:34am

And I'd probably say, "bloody hell, where's my hairline gone?"

11:34 am
BE11:34am

 Mixed Outlook – RBS continues to target FY19 cost reduction of £300m, implying FY19 adj. costs of c£7.0bn, which is consistent with consensus. However the “ongoing impact of Brexit uncertainty on the economy, and associated delay in business borrowing decisions, is likely to make income growth more challenging near term.” While UK PBB loan growth of 1.1% qoq is impressive, Commercial loans contracted by 0.6% qoq, making the 2-3% FY19 CPB growth target ambitious.
 Adj. Revenue 5% Miss — Adj. revenues of £3.1bn are -6% yoy and -5% vs cons. with weaker NII (6% below) and non-interest income (4% below). Comparisons to prior periods (and consensus) are complicated by reclassification of NWM (Natwest Markets) funding costs from Non-II to NII. The NIM, excl. NWM, appears to be flat qoq, at 2.07%, with a reduction in central liquidity offsetting competitive pressures. The miss therefore looks to be mainly due to non-NII, post a weaker NWM result.
 Expenses 1% Heavier — Underlying expenses of £1.7bn are -3% yoy, but +1% vs consensus. The decline yoy is mainly due to lower headcount and operating efficiencies, with strongest yoy reduction in PBB

BE11:35am

... (-6%) and Intl (-5%) but offset by increases in Ulster (+10%) and Central (+26%).

wayneJ Re Bayer - isn't the issue the lottery of the US court system. The BP 'experience' makes foreign companies and investors rather 'cautious'.
BE11:35am

Impairments Much Lighter — 1Q19 net impairments of £86m (11bps LLR) is well below consensus. The beat was driven by net writebacks of £16m in Markets, £11m in Ulster Bank and ‘only’ £112m net impairments in CPB (30bps).

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Implications — We expect to see low single-digit consensus EPS downgrades, on the weaker top-line. However the message on capital return remains reassuring

BE11:35am

And Goldman off the conference call.

Excel Developer @waynej: 1974, oil quadrupled and more idiosyncratic to UK Ted Heath government brought down by miners' strike etc.
BE11:36am

1.reach 14% CET1 ratio by 2021). Specifically, might have to propose something to Board at 1H19 results if by then nothing else happened (e.g. buyback), as otherwise capital ratio would edge toward 17%.
Alawwal Bank merger: Expects merger to complete in 2Q. This would (i)
2.release £5bn of RWAs, (ii) at current share prices, would result in an P&L profit in the order of a few hundred million and (iii) result in positive contribution from FX recycling (£1.5bn in 2Q and 3Q), which however would be neutral from capital and TNAV perspective.
Mortgages: Sees current market pricing implying a greater than 15% ROE for RBS. Market
3.remains highly competitive, with spread between existing book and new businesses broadly constant at 80-90 bp.
Commercial Banking weakness: Has seen customers paying down debt and 4.holding cash and sitting on the sidelines, which led to the weaker revenue figure.
NatWest Markets: Despite weaker print this quarter, continues to see NatWest 5.Markets revenue capabilities at around £1.3-1.4bn per annum.
We are Buy-rated on RBS. We value the shares using an ROTE/COE-based methodology and our 12-month price target is 395p.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Hate banks.

undefined
wayneJ Isn't it DeLorean? PS why would u ever buy one when you can hire one for £100 - presumably that would be for all time??? See https://www.carandclassic.co.uk/list/111/
Plato the Cook It’s not the Avengers without Emma Peel
BE11:37am

Oh, the first line of the Goldman thing seems to have fallen off. It should say "Capital return: expects to return further capital during 2019 (in line with target to reach 15% ...."

BornCynic @Maudise - I have been in the same cinema and have seen audiences of less than 10 people. There were three showings of the film last night and they were all full. Capacity of 300 - 400. I am tempted to go out and buy Cineworld shares..........
wayneJ Are we wiser as to why the RBS CEO is planning to leave?

(@Wayne: he's 61, he was due to go this year and it was the AGM. I fail to see what's fishy about any of this.)

.... Cineworld?

11:40 am
Cineworld Group PLC (CINE:LSE): Last: 315.74, up 0.6434 (+0.20%), High: 318.40, Low: 314.70, Volume: 287.39k
Maudise 3 Cineworld Shares = 1 Adult Ticket. good value 3-4-1!
GBKrona @WayneJ - I doubt any of us could stand over 5 years as RBS CEO either
wayneJ @BE - whilst Omaha insurance conglomerate CEOs continue to have fun at 88? :-) Just seemed surprised that there was not an accompanying announcement of a replacement which always suggests the board was caught unaware?
BE11:41am

There are a number of issues with the investment case beyond the arguably one-turn benefit of another superhero movie.

BornCynic I was not serious BE.......
BornCynic I was merely noting that someone is making a heap of cash.
AMALtd @ThManwithaLongChin more like every month now...
BE11:42am

It is, nevertheless, an argument. Here's Berenberg from earlier in the month.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

If “The Avengers: Endgame” lives up to its
potential and breaks box office records (the best opening weekend, for
example), we believe it should put another nail in the coffin of structural
concerns about the cinema market, which could contribute to a further rerating.
Furthermore, outside of the box office boost, the strength in prebookings
bodes well for Cineworld, considering that booking fees are not
shared with the studios (unlike the ticket price), and therefore drop
through to the bottom line at close to a 100% margin.

BE11:43am

[T]he movie slate for 2019 is exceptionally strong, with “The Lion King” (19 July) and “Star Wars” (20 December) likely to challenge “The Avengers: Endgame” for the biggest takings this year. Outside of the slate, the second half should bring other big news in the form of completed refurbishments of US sites, with renovations underway at a number of major Regal sites (including New York’s Union Square).

BE11:43am

Despite being up by
c15% ytd, Cineworld still trades at just c7.8x 2019E EV/EBITDA with a 10%
FCF yield. In six months’ time, attention will likely have turned to 2020
multiples. We think that with continued good news, the shares could quite
plausibly re-rate to 9x 2020E EV/EBITDA by then (with lower net debt).
That would put the shares at c410p – c35% higher than current levels –
while shareholders enjoy a c4.3% dividend yield in the meantime.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Which is fine, but you're taking about The Lion King reboot and yet another Star Wars movie pulling cinema admissions out of long term decline

GBKrona How much less would Cineworld make if people did not eat and drink pure junk during screenings?
BE11:45am

There are bumps but the general trend is lower, by about 20% since 2007.

BornCynic I note that this cinema had introduced "flexible" tickets for an extra quid. I can see why now - the money goes straight to the cinema.
BE11:46am

You also have use of airline pricing flex, bundled offers and club type structures that erode ARPU.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

And rising costs -- labour in particular

Maudise What does the flexible ticket do (Not been and paid for so long, all trips are funded by bank account give aways
BE11:47am

And with Cineworld you have a long tail of US cinemas needing investment.

wayneJ Serious question: Am I right in thinking that 10 yr inflation linked gilts imply 2 % or so NEGATIVE inflation in the UK? Does that not screw up all banks that have lent vs property; all infrastructure funds and lots of pension schemes?
BE11:47am

Which will be tricky for a business that's already very levered.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

And with the uncertainty of IFRS 16

BE11:48am

And with the obvious problem of mall footfall

BE11:48am

And around which there have been questions regarding management quality.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

I'd not be piling in. But, hey, your money.

undefined
BE11:48am

Uber S1's out. https://www.sec.go...59/d647752ds1a.htm

11:48 am
BE11:49am

Meanwhile, over at Uber V1.0 ......

Stagecoach Group PLC (SGC:LSE): Last: 121.70, up 6.2 (+5.37%), High: 122.50, Low: 114.50, Volume: 2.43m
Maudise OVerly simplistic Wayne - low yields on 10Y also show risk appetite as well as inflation expectations.
BE11:49am

You'll have seen the £60m buyback news yesterday.

wayneJ @Maudise - good point. Alternatively I am thinking are the inflation linked gilts mis-priced.
Excel Developer @WayneJ: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/statistics/yield-curves and scroll down to "UK instantaneous implied inflation forward curve (gilts)"
11:50 am
BE11:50am

Which can be seen in a number of ways.

BE11:51am

One way it can be seen is Brian Souter and Ann Gloag taking the company private very gradually with shareholders' own money.

wayneJ @Excel - thanks - so that is actually saying that the curve is implying 3 -4% inflation. Now confused - suspect I need to master inflation linked bond pricing.
BE11:52am

Which, once the US business is sold, can really kick on. Here's RBC.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

n our view, with FY20E-FY21E 6%-7% FCF yield, a FY18 effective average interest cost of 3.7% and ND/EBITDA FY21E at 1.5x suggests there may be scope for further SBBs in time - absent M&A. In effect, by retiring equity and cautiously lifting debt we think this could see the company slowing taken private stage-by-stage in some scenarios.

Excel Developer or from Fulcrum asset mgtmt (which is Gavyn Davies boutique) https://www.fulcrumasset.com/uk-iach/wp-content/uploads/sites/5/2018/05/bond2.jpg
BE11:53am

The other thing we have today is Citi turning positive on valuation.

BE11:53am

Following the recent reset the shares now trade at their lowest in 15 years with P/E (ex-rail) at c.10x and EV/EBITDA (ex-rail) at 5.5x for 2019E. However, with the impending exit from the beleaguered UK Rail sector and the sale of the underperforming North American division we see a significantly de-risked portfolio with a cash generative UK Bus business with stabilizing operating profits and which has scope for opex efficiency gains to offset further negative demand or opex inflation. Upgrade to Buy.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Does "scope for opex efficiency gains to offset further negative demand or opex inflation" mean cutting routes?

BE11:53am

As UK Regional Bus accounts for c. 90% of our valuation we have undertaken a detailed analysis of its 18 largest Regional Bus subsidiaries. The results suggest that if passenger volumes continue to fall the company has scope to achieve opex efficiency gains; however, as our base case we expect management to use the available scope to offset opex inflation and otherwise higher fare increases rather than to drive margins higher and risk exacerbating volume declines further.

BE11:53am

Yes. I think it means cutting routes.

11:53 am
BE11:54am

With the sale of the North American division Stagecoach will see its leverage fall to the lowest level since 2011. We expect management to update investors on their intentions for capital allocation with the full year results in June (for which we have opened a positive catalyst watch). The company has already announced a £60m buyback (c. 9% of the market cap) as of the 25th April to be conducted over 12 months. Potential other uses of the cash on its balance sheet include UK Bus acquisitions from other operators or the early retirement of its more expensive debt.

BE11:54am

We value Stagecoach on a sum-of-the-parts basis, applying calendar 2019E EBITDA multiples for the Bus divisions, Rail franchises are valued by discounting back the sum of expected franchise earnings (WACC of 7.7%, cost of equity 10%) owing to the fixed-term nature of the contracts.

wayneJ @Excel So this all implies that real yields (nominal - inflation) is rising which would suggest the BoE is not providing enough liquidity / funding etc into the economy or we are all in despair and exercise our preference to fester rather than deploy capital
Excel Developer @waynej: I don't think it's that complicated, The 10-year yield can be deconstructed into three components: short-term real rates, inflation expectations and the term premium, a catch-all that reflects technical and structural factors” https://quillintelligence.com/welcome/
BE11:55am

By the way, why is Stagecoach doing a £60m share buyback rather than retiring its more expensive debt lines?

BornCynic I should note that the cinema was putting itself out for hire "play your favourite video game on the big screen". Which I thought was either great management trying to squeeze every penny out of the business or an act of desperation. Take your pick........
11:56 am
BE11:56am

Perhaps that's something to ask Souter and Gloag, Stagecoach's second and third biggest shareholders respectively.

undefined

11:58 am

BE11:59am

Oh, and Intel's soft warning overnight.

cracklenpop @PlatoTheCook ….or Joanna Lumley

12:00 pm

John Fallon, Chief Executive said:

“We are off to a strong start to the year, having laid good foundations in 2018. We continue to make progress against our strategic priorities, and we are bringing exciting new products and capabilities to market in 2019 which will continue to accelerate our move to digital. We expect our sales to stabilise this year and to increase our underlying profit further."

12:01 pm

BE12:04pm

Pearson Q1 results never tell us very much about the full year: the business is 2H-weighted and the Q1 mix is favourable (more weighted to the parts of the business that grow than the parts that don’t). But this year they have delivered organic revenue growth of 2%, slightly below our estimated 2.8%. And the focus will be (as usual) on North America Higher Education Courseware, which saw organic revenues “decline slightly” – a phrase that typically means -1-2% in the Pearson lexicon. This compares to “growing slightly” in 1Q18. Pearson management is pointing to an easy comp on returns (related to how provisions were set) in 1Q18 – and no such easy comp this time. But the rhetoric from all the college textbook publishers has focused on December weakness being exacerbated by revenue falling out of December into January. That is why we (and we believe others) expected modest growth (we had +2%) in this revenue line in Q1.

Management is reiterating its guidance of 0% to -5% for the year in NA HE Courseware. Probably this results in Q1 doesn’t tell us that much about where they will land, because this is a small quarter. But optically a decline in Q1 is not a positive for sentiment. All other guidance has also been reiterated.
